news-item.title: Exxon says it's completed soil cleanup from Arkansas pipeline spill
news-item.author: Lance Murray
news-item.text: Irving, Texas-based Exxon Mobil Corp. (NYSE: XOM) has completed the cleanup of soil contaminated during last year's oil spill in Mayflower, Ark., according to documents the company filed with the Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality.The Arkansas Democrat reported that the revised report was submitted last week to the state and is subject the department's approval. The Pegasus Pipeline ruptured in March 2013, spilling crude oil into the suburban neighborhood. Got Energy? Sign up for our Energy Inc. newsletter here . In November, Exxon was hit with a $2.6 million fine by federal regulators in association with the spill. Regulators said Exxon did not follow policies for testing and reporting risks associated with the pipeline. According to the report, Exxon recommended more work be done to remove remaining oil from a cove and drainage ways at Lake Conway and that the company has agreed to do weekly sheen monitoring and sheen removal in the cove. It will take other measures, including replacing booms that absorb oil from the water at least every three months,  the Greenfield Reporter said.
